CONTRA COSTA POWER PLANT RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1 BACKGROUND
Mirant Delta, LLC (Mirant) owns and operates Contra Costa Power Plant (CCPP), an electric power generating facility located east of Antioch, California in Contra Costa County.  There are seven existing units at CCPP: Units 1-3 which have been retired, Units 4 and 5 which continue to operate as synchronous condensers for support of the regional transmission system, and Units 6 and 7 which continue to operate for electric power generation.  In 2001, Mirant began construction of a new combined cycle power generation unit (Unit 8) at the CCPP site.  In 2002, Mirant suspended construction activities associated with Unit 8 and the Unit 8 project was placed into a suspended status.  In 2006, ownership of the Unit 8 asset was transferred from Mirant to Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) and construction activities have been resumed by PG&E.

Mirant has retrofit the existing Unit 7 at CCPP with a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system in order to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), as required to comply with Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD) Regulation 9, Rule 11, "Nitrogen Oxides and Carbon Monoxide from Electric Power Generating Steam Boilers".  Mirant completed the SCR retrofit of Unit 7 in November of 2001.  At the time that the Unit 7 SCR system was designed and constructed, Mirant had planned to also retrofit Unit 6 with an SCR system.  Since that time, the project to retrofit Unit 6 with an SCR system has been cancelled.

The SCR technology utilizes aqueous ammonia to reduce NOx emissions from the generating units.  The concentration of ammonia in the aqueous solution is 29.4 % by weight.  This substance is listed as a hazardous material under both California and federal regulations.

In order to prevent accidental releases of hazardous materials and to reduce their potential impact on the public and the environment, a federal program was esta

blished in 1990 as described in Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act.  The California Office of Emergency Services established the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur.  The CalARP Program specifies the regulated substances, oversees the federal requirements, and determines the requirements for the preparation of a Risk Management Plan (RMP) and offsite accidental release consequence analysis.  In Contra Costa County, the Administering Agency overseeing the CalARP program is the Contra Costa County Health Services Department (CCCHSD).

Since the quantity of aqueous ammonia that is stored and used at the Contra Costa Power Plant (CCPP) is greater than both the Federal and State Threshold Quantities, a RMP is required.  As shown in this RMP, even a highly improbable worst-case release from the CCPP aqueous ammonia system will not cause the toxic endpoint concentration for ammonia (200 ppmv) to occur offsite.  In addition, the more stringent 30-minute Short-Term Public Emergency Limit (STPEL) proposed by the National Research Council (75 ppmv) will not be exceeded at any neighboring residences or businesses as a result of the hypothetical worst-case release.   Also, CCPP has not experienced any accidental releases during the last five years that caused an offsite impact.  Accordingly, this process qualifies for a Program 1 RMP under both the CalARP and federal regulations.  In order to fulfill the Program 1 requirements, the following actions were completed: 

    - Analyze the worst-case release scenario.
    - Document that the nearest public receptor is beyond the distance to a toxic endpoint.
    - Document that no hazardous material accidents have occurred at CCPP in the past 5 years.
    - Ensure that response actions have been coordinated with local emergency planning and response agencies.
    - Certify in the RMP that "no ad

ditional measures are necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental releases."

To ensure continued compliance with the CalARP regulations, Mirant will update this RMP within five years of its initial submission or most recent update, before any additional regulated substance is brought onsite, before additional aqueous ammonia storage is installed, or if there is a major change that may alter the offsite consequence analysis.

1.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Mirant is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner.  It is the policy of Mirant to conduct business in a manner that protects the environment and the safety and health of the public and its employees by: 

    - Meeting or surpassing all environmental laws, regulations and permit requirements, and verifying this commitment through environmental auditing. 
    - Seeking to ensure that environmental laws, regulations and permit requirements are based on sound science and cost-effective technology. 
    - Pursuing opportunities to enhance the quality of the environment. 
    - Promoting public and employee understanding of environmental issues and the company's environmental activities. 
    - Establishing company and organizational environmental goals and implementation plans. 
    - Ensuring that employees are aware of their individual roles and responsibilities in the implementation of this environmental policy.

In an effort to continue to improve the environmental, safety and health performance at CCPP, the following lists many of the specific environmental, safety and health programs that are implemented at the facility:
    - Facility Emergency Plan
    - Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan
    - Hazardous Materials Business Plan
    - Oil Spill Response Plan
    - Safety & Health Program (Injury & Illness Prevention Pro

gram)
    - Hazard Communication Program
    - Fuel Oil Tank Farm Operating Procedures
    - Contra Costa Power Plant Operating Procedures
    - Respiratory Protection Program
    - Hearing Conservation Program
    - Confined Space Program
    - Evacuation Policy
    - Asbestos Policy
    - Bloodborne Pathogens Policy
    - Lead Control Policy
    - Contractor and New Employee Safety Orientation Policy

On-going personnel training at CCPP includes, but is not limited to the following:
    - Ammonia Awareness	
    - Asbestos Awareness
    - First Responder Awareness
    - Hazard Communication
    - Safety & Health Program
    - Personal Protective Equipment Awareness
    - Hearing Conservation
    - Respiratory Protection Awareness
    - Hazardous Waste Management
    - Bloodborne Pathogens
    - Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan
    - Confined Space 
    - Ergonomics
    - First Aid/Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR)/Automated External Defibrillator (AED)
    - Lockout/Tagout
    - Lead Awareness
    - Incipient Fire Response
    - Fall Protection

In a continued effort to improve and ensure proper implementation of the environmental, safety and health policies, the following measures are regularly employed:
    - Mirant's Compliance Audit Program - Mirant's corporate office from Atlanta, Georgia performs periodic environmental, safety and health audits.  The purpose of these audits is to assess the overall adequacy of the environmental, safety and health management system and to provide reasonable assurance of compliance with all applicable regulations and Company requirements.  Corporate audits involve visual walk downs of the facility, as well as interviews with management, operations and maintenance personnel.  A compliance review report is prepared with recommendations and resolutions. 
    - Mirant California Safety Committee - The Safety Committee is composed of the Safety and Health Manager, the Safety Coor

dinator and at least one representative from each department and meets for times a year to identify safety and health issues and develop solutions.
    - Facility Management Compliance Walkdown Audits - In-house audits are conducted by walkdowns of the various facilities noting any hazardous conditions or housekeeping issues.  These are performed by plant personnel and safety and health representatives.  Issues are resolved immediately or work orders are created for longer term projects.
    - On-going Refresher Training - All Power Plant Technicians (Operations, Electrical & Mechanical Maintenance, Support Services, Technical Services) and Environmental, Safety & Health personnel receive annual refresher training, or more frequent training if necessary, about emergency response plans and relevant safety and health issues.  Additional hazardous materials training is conducted for personnel working directly with the aqueous ammonia systems.
    - Master Tailboard Safety Meetings - Monthly Master Tailboard meetings have been replaced with daily safety tailboards by each crew at each of our facilities.  Each crew conducts a daily safety tailboard in which safety and health issues and concerns are raised, safety & health training is conducted, or other safety and health information is communicated.

The release prevention programs to be implemented in conjunction with this RMP will strengthen the existing safety and environmental programs at CCPP.

1.3 STORAGE AND HANDLING OF REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The only federal and CalARP regulated substance that is stored and handled onsite at CCPP is aqueous ammonia, which is used in the SCR system to reduce NOx emissions.  In the SCR system, aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tank, to a vaporizer, which produces a uniform distribution of gaseous ammonia that is then mixed with the flue gas from the boiler and passed over a catalyst to reduce the NOx emissions from the stack exhaust. 

The aqueous ammonia storage fa

cility is located near the northern portion of the developed property of the Contra Costa Power Plant, south of Units 6 and 7.  The location of the aqueous ammonia storage facility has been selected largely on the basis of safety considerations.  This location maximizes the distance from the property fence line, reducing any potential offsite impacts due to a spill, while minimizing the piping distance to the Units.  In addition, the location was chosen because of the facility area's low occupancy, its easy access for delivery trucks, and to distance the aqueous ammonia storage system from combustible equipment and minimize potential impacts to plant personnel.

The aqueous ammonia storage facility consists of a truck unloading station and three aqueous ammonia storage tanks.  The storage facility has been designed and constructed to receive and store aqueous ammonia for three different SCR systems: the Unit 7 SCR system that is currently in operation, a planned SCR system for Unit 6 that has not been installed and a SCR system for the new power generating unit (Unit 8) that has been transferred to PG&E's ownership.  At the present time, only the aqueous ammonia storage tank for the Unit 7 SCR system is in service.  The aqueous ammonia storage tanks that were installed for the Unit 6 SCR system and for PG&E's new power generating unit are currently empty.

The storage facility that currently services the SCR system for Unit 7 and that was designed for two additional SCR systems includes three 21,200-gallon capacity carbon steel storage tanks, approximately 10 feet in diameter by 38 feet long.  The effective maximum volume of each storage tank is limited to 20,000 gallons through administrative controls which include operating procedures that require a check of the storage tank level prior to filling the tank to confirm that the tank has sufficient free volume to accept the ammonia without exceeding 20,000 gallons.  The tanks have been designed and constructed in

compliance with Uniform Building Code Seismic Zone 4, Uniform Fire Code Article 80, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels.  The tanks have a maximum design pressure and temperature of 50 pounds per square inch  gauge (psig) and 120 F, respectively. 

The aqueous ammonia tanks are supported horizontally on concrete foundations within a walled containment basin approximately 68 feet long by 44 feet wide, that slopes to a centrally located, covered sump beneath the tanks and running the length of the containment area.  This sump is 6 feet wide and 12 feet deep and provides a volume sufficient to hold 100 percent of the contents of one aqueous ammonia storage tank, plus the maximum rainfall recorded in 24 hours in the past 43 years (3.03 inches, WRCC 1955-1998).   Pumps for forwarding the aqueous ammonia to the SCR systems and for unloading aqueous ammonia from delivery tanker trucks are also located within the containment basin.

Aqueous ammonia is delivered to the Contra Costa Power Plant via tanker truck.  Individual tanker trucks can transport up to 6,500 gallons of aqueous ammonia.  The concrete slab under the truck unloading station has been designed to contain the contents of one full truck and is sloped to quickly drain any accidental releases of aqueous ammonia into the central covered containment sump.  Each storage tank has an unloading station consisting of an ammonia fill line, where aqueous ammonia is fed from the delivery truck to the tank, and a vapor return line where vapor pressure between the tank and the truck is equalized.  

The aqueous ammonia is pumped through 3/4 inch stainless steel piping from the storage tanks to the SCR injection grid.  The portion of the piping between the storage tank containment area and the Unit 7 SCR injection grid that crosses the roadway and parking areas is contained within a covered trench that protects the piping

from vehicular traffic and provides secondary containment.  The portion of the piping that exits the covered trench and delivers aqueous ammonia to the SCR injection grid is contained within larger diameter PVC piping for all stretches as per the request of the Contra Costa Consolidated Fire District.  Therefore, secondary containment is provided for all sections of aqueous ammonia piping.

The aqueous ammonia delivery and injection facilities for the Unit 7 SCR system includes two aqueous ammonia feed pumps, ammonia vaporization equipment, and an ammonia injection grid.  In the SCR system, aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tank to spray nozzles inside the ammonia vaporizer unit that is mounted on the vaporizor skid near the SCR reactor.  The spray droplets are then mixed with a hot air diluent stream in the vaporizer to evaporate the ammonia.  The vaporizer produces a uniform distribution of gaseous ammonia in the diluent stream.  The diluent stream is then transported to the injection grid.  

The injection grid is located upstream of the SCR reactor.  This allows more thorough mixing of the ammonia-laden diluent stream with the turbulent flue gas from the boiler.  Although the oxidation-reduction reaction is initiated by the injection of ammonia at the injection grid, all of the reaction is completed in the SCR reactor by passing the mixture over a catalyst composed primarily of titanium and vanadium oxides.  The treated flue gas, containing a small amount of residual NOX and excess ammonia, is discharged out of the stack.

The SCR process is controlled with feed-forward and feedback control loops.  An upstream NOX analyzer measures the NOX concentration at the SCR reactor inlet.  A downstream analyzer measures the total NOx concentration downstream of the SCR reactor outlet.  The ammonia demand signal, which regulates the rate at which aqueous ammonia is pumped to the vaporizer, is determined from both NOx analyzers.

The aqueous ammonia soluti

on that is used for the Unit 7 SCR system at CCPP is 29.4 percent ammonia by weight, with the balance of the weight being water.  Aqueous ammonia is a corrosive material although the degree of danger associated with the substance is considered to be minor.  Ammonia is not a known carcinogen, but it poses acute and chronic non-carcinogenic health hazards to the respiratory system and chronic non-carcinogenic health hazards as skin irritations or other effects.  Acute health hazards are those that occur from short exposures to airborne ammonia vapor, whereas chronic health effects are those that occur as a result of long-term exposures.

Though there is some insoluble ammonia present in the ammonia solution, the solution has a very low vapor pressure compared to anhydrous ammonia, a more hazardous compound also used for SCR systems.  The ammonia present will not readily vaporize if the solution is released to the atmosphere.  If the ammonia evaporates from the solution, the ammonia vapor is irritating at levels above a few parts per million volume (ppmv) and acutely toxic in high concentrations.  A one-hour average ammonia vapor concentration above 200 ppmv could cause respiratory irritation to exposed individuals.  According to the National Research Council, exposure at the 75 ppmv STPEL level "should not result in serious effects, but would result in strong odor, lacrimation, and irritation of the upper respiratory tract (nose and throat), but no incapacitation or prevention of self-rescue."  

Ammonia vapor is flammable in air at concentrations of 16 percent to 25 percent, but requires a very high temperature source for ignition.  Ammonia concentrations directly above an aqueous ammonia spill never approach these concentrations; therefore aqueous ammonia has no explosive flammability potential.

1.5 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Safety was the foremost consideration when designing the aqueous ammonia unloading and storage facility.  The location of t

he aqueous ammonia storage facility was selected to be in a low occupancy area of the plant at a maximum distance from the property fence line, to reduce potential offsite impacts from a spill.

The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are enclosed within a walled containment basin that slopes to a centrally located, covered sump beneath the tanks that runs the length of the containment area.  There also is a walled containment pad under the tanker truck unloading facility that drains rapidly into the covered sump under the tanks in the event of a spill.

Many accident prevention safeguards have been implemented within the aqueous ammonia storage area.  For example in the event of a power outage, standby power needed for all required electrical systems, such as monitors and alarms, is provided by the Uninteruptable Power Supply system.  Also hot work permits are required for specific activities that present the potential for fire, and personnel involved in such operations have received appropriate training.  

Other safety features of the aqueous ammonia storage facility include:
    - Ammonia area monitoring system with audible and visible alarms,
    - Eyewash and shower station,
    - Piping and connections for washdown of containment basin with clean water,
    - Permanent lighting,
    - Lightning protection,
    - Truck barrier posts to protect ammonia tanks and delivery lines,
    - Liquid level indication and high-level alarm for each tank, easily visible from the unloading position,
    - Tank level and pressure indicators and pressure relief valves and alarms in the plant control room,
    - Shut-off valves located on the tank fill lines, which will close automatically if the emergency high-level alarm is triggered,
    - Local manual controls for all pumps,
    - Vacuum breakers on each tank
    - Safety equipment (for two personnel) including:  two sets of escape respirators, ammonia cartridges for the respirators, two pairs of ammonia-resista

nt gloves, two pairs of ammonia-resistant boots, two ammonia-resistant aprons, two pairs of goggles, one first aid kit, and one fire extinguisher.  

Area sensors have been installed in the aqueous ammonia storage facility area and at the vaporization skid to monitor for ambient ammonia concentrations.  Alarms are designed to annunciate in the control room, with local audible alarms for ammonia releases at the facilities.

To minimize impacts from accidental releases, workers have been trained in the safe handling of hazardous materials, use of response equipment, procedures for mitigation of a release, and coordination with local emergency response organizations.  To avoid or minimize impacts from the accidental releases of hazardous materials, nonhazardous or less hazardous materials will be used, where possible, and engineering controls will be implemented.  For example, aqueous ammonia was selected for the SCR system over anhydrous ammonia, because it is less hazardous.

1.6 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
During the past 5 years at the facility there have been no accidents involving regulated substances or other extremely hazardous substances that have resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.

Accidents at CCPP have been avoided by adhering to the safety and environmental programs listed in Section 1.2, continually improving the personnel safety training program and adhering to a strict maintenance program for all equipment involved with the storage and handling of hazardous substances.  

1.7 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
CCPP has coordinated emergency response programs with the CCCHSD and the Contra Costa Consolidated Fire District.  Periodically the fire district inspects the facilities that store and handle flammable hazardous materials at CCPP to ensure that the applicable Uniform Fire Code requirements are being met.

The Contra Costa Consolidated Fire District visits approximately once per year to practice a simulated emergency at the plant to ensure timely, effective, safe response plans.  

In the unlikely event of an accidental release of a hazardous substance, CCPP utilizes an alphanumeric paging system as its primary emergency notification system for all onsite personnel.  The system provides written information regarding the emergency.  If the release could result in an offsite public health concern, the emergency coordinator or incident commander shall notify Contra Costa County officials to determine if the community warning system (CWS) should be activated.  All community notification, whether initiated manually or automatically, will be coordinated by the Contra Costa Consolidated Fire District. 

The above notification procedures are explained in detail in the Facility Emergency Plan along with procedures for minimizing the impact of an incident, appropriate response activities for each hazardous substance onsite, and the phone numbers to contact both on and offsite emergency response personnel.

1.8 SAFETY IMPROVEMENT PLANS
To continue operating a safe accident-free facility, the safety features described in this document and specifically in Section 1.5, Accidental Release Prevention Program, have been implemented during the construction of the aqueous ammonia storage and handling facilities.  Regular equipment inspections, maintenance and safety reviews will ensure continued safe operations at CCPP.  Mirant California's Safety Committee meets at least four times a year to review and develop the safety and health programs for the Delta Power Plants.
